text: The second section of the WTR addresses a broad range of issues that are of immediate and vital interest to  the membership of the WTO. This year’s theme is trade and development. text: The second section of the WTR addresses a broad range of issues that are of immediate and vital interest to  the membership of the WTO. This year’s theme is trade and development. Starting from a broad although  brief discussion of development and the relationship between trade and development, the Report goes on  to analyse how the Doha Development Agenda can contribute to growth and development in developing  countries.

triple: <Some>	<>	<years>	<>	<more momentous>	<>
text: The Director-General of the WTO would never declare any year unimportant or unchallenging for the  trading system. But some years are undoubtedly more momentous than others, and this is one of them.  The Fifth Ministerial Conference in Cancún in September is not the end of the Doha negotiations, but a very  important landmark on the road to completion. At Cancún, Ministers will have to take stock of progress in the  negotiations, provide political guidance and take certain decisions. This is not simply about meeting targets  and completing an agenda – it is about creating conditions for advancement in all countries, and in particular  about expanding opportunities for developing countries through their more effective inclusion in the trading  system.

text: The Director-General of the WTO would never declare any year unimportant or unchallenging for the  trading system. But some years are undoubtedly more momentous than others, and this is one of them.  The Fifth Ministerial Conference in Cancún in September is not the end of the Doha negotiations, but a very  important landmark on the road to completion. At Cancún, Ministers will have to take stock of progress in the  negotiations, provide political guidance and take certain decisions. This is not simply about meeting targets  and completing an agenda – it is about creating conditions for advancement in all countries, and in particular  about expanding opportunities for developing countries through their more effective inclusion in the trading  system.

triple: <Statistics>	<Statistics is a field involving the collection and analysis of data, as mentioned in the context of trade statistics and tariff information.>	<Group>	<The relation 'Group' indicates that Statistics is part of a collective entity within the Economic Research and Statistics Division, as noted in the text.>	<Economic Research and Statistics Division>	<The Economic Research and Statistics Division is a department responsible for economic research and statistical analysis, as indicated by its coordination of trade statistics and tariff information.>
text: The World Trade Report has been written under the general direction of Patrick Low, Director of the Economic  Research and Statistics Division.  The main authors of the Report are Bijit Bora, K. Michael Finger, Marion  Jansen, Alexander Keck, Patrick Low, Hildegunn Nordas, Roberta Piermartini and Robert Teh. Trade statistics  and tariff information were provided by the Statistics Group of the Economic Research and Statistics Division,  co-ordinated by Guy Karsenty, Julia de Verteuil, Andreas Maurer and Jürgen Richtering.

triple: <Development>	<A broad topic of immediate and vital interest to WTO membership, linked to trade and the Doha Development Agenda's role in fostering growth in developing countries.>	<is related to>	<The connection arises from the discussion on how trade influences development and the role of the Doha Development Agenda in promoting growth in developing nations.>	<trade>	<Central to the WTO's focus, trade is analyzed in relation to development, particularly through the Doha Development Agenda's impact on developing countries' growth.>
text: The second section of the WTR addresses a broad range of issues that are of immediate and vital interest to  the membership of the WTO. This year’s theme is trade and development. Starting from a broad although  brief discussion of development and the relationship between trade and development, the Report goes on  to analyse how the Doha Development Agenda can contribute to growth and development in developing  countries.

text: Second, as governments formulate their positions in respect of the many issues on the Doha Agenda requiring  decision, an important point to keep in mind is that the effective pursuit of national interests requires joint  action around shared objectives. That means joint responsibility for an effective process of give and take.  Countries hardly ever obtain everything they want in negotiations, but it is deeply fallacious to see an outcome  yielding no result as a better option than one that might require hard work and patience, but offers something  to all parties.

text: The Director-General of the WTO would never declare any year unimportant or unchallenging for the  trading system. But some years are undoubtedly more momentous than others, and this is one of them.  The Fifth Ministerial Conference in Cancún in September is not the end of the Doha negotiations, but a very  important landmark on the road to completion. At Cancún, Ministers will have to take stock of progress in the  negotiations, provide political guidance and take certain decisions. This is not simply about meeting targets  and completing an agenda – it is about creating conditions for advancement in all countries, and in particular  about expanding opportunities for developing countries through their more effective inclusion in the trading  system.

text: The Director-General of the WTO would never declare any year unimportant or unchallenging for the  trading system. But some years are undoubtedly more momentous than others, and this is one of them.  The Fifth Ministerial Conference in Cancún in September is not the end of the Doha negotiations, but a very  important landmark on the road to completion. At Cancún, Ministers will have to take stock of progress in the  negotiations, provide political guidance and take certain decisions. This is not simply about meeting targets  and completing an agenda – it is about creating conditions for advancement in all countries, and in particular  about expanding opportunities for developing countries through their more effective inclusion in the trading  system.

text: Focusing particularly on this last point, the Report examines how the Doha negotiations and work programme  can contribute to more effective and intensified engagement by developing countries in the WTO, building  on new opportunities generated by policy change in both developed and developing countries. The Report  divides its analysis into segments dealing with market access questions, policies aimed at facilitating openness  for development, policies for managing openness within the WTO rules, and issues relating to the possible  expansion of the WTO’s negotiating agenda. In each instance, the Report identifies basic issues and assesses  options in terms of their implications for development.

text: The Director-General of the WTO would never declare any year unimportant or unchallenging for the  trading system. But some years are undoubtedly more momentous than others, and this is one of them.  The Fifth Ministerial Conference in Cancún in September is not the end of the Doha negotiations, but a very  important landmark on the road to completion. At Cancún, Ministers will have to take stock of progress in the  negotiations, provide political guidance and take certain decisions. This is not simply about meeting targets  and completing an agenda – it is about creating conditions for advancement in all countries, and in particular  about expanding opportunities for developing countries through their more effective inclusion in the trading  system.

triple: <Analysis>	<>	<highlights>	<>	<well-known fact>	<>
text: The Report’s analysis of trends in non-oil commodity markets highlights the well-known fact that developing  countries economically reliant on basic commodities have suffered in recent years from price declines and  continuing volatility. A range of solutions are on offer to address this problem, but some of them have proven  less than effective in the past. Fresh thinking is needed, both on the question of what can be done in respect  of the commodity markets themselves, and how developing countries might diversify their economies away  from excessive reliance on a narrow production base. Trade liberalization has a role to play, particularly in the  areas of agriculture and tariff escalation.

triple: <Agenda>	<>	<advancing>	<>	<multilateral>	<>
text: Regional trade agreements have burgeoned in the last decade or so. This can be good news and bad news.  Such agreements are good news when they bring regions closer together, create new profitable trading  opportunities and set the scene for more inclusive market-opening. They are bad news when they discriminate  unduly against third parties and frustrate the attainment of multilateral objectives built on non-discrimination.  No government has challenged the view that the multilateral trading system must retain its primary unifying  role at the core of trade relations among nations. Given this unity of purpose, governments need to do more  to ensure the coherence and compatibility of regional trading arrangements with the multilateral trading  system. This implies a strong commitment to advancing the multilateral agenda as well as ensuring that  regional agreements are designed to support and not to compete with the WTO system.

triple: <Give and Take>	<A process requiring joint action around shared objectives to effectively pursue national interests.>	<process>	<The 'process' signifies the method through which joint action and shared objectives lead to effective outcomes in negotiations.>	<effective>	<Denotes the desired result of the give and take process, emphasizing successful negotiation outcomes that benefit all parties.>
text: Second, as governments formulate their positions in respect of the many issues on the Doha Agenda requiring  decision, an important point to keep in mind is that the effective pursuit of national interests requires joint  action around shared objectives. That means joint responsibility for an effective process of give and take.  Countries hardly ever obtain everything they want in negotiations, but it is deeply fallacious to see an outcome  yielding no result as a better option than one that might require hard work and patience, but offers something  to all parties.

text: Regional trade agreements have burgeoned in the last decade or so. This can be good news and bad news.  Such agreements are good news when they bring regions closer together, create new profitable trading  opportunities and set the scene for more inclusive market-opening. They are bad news when they discriminate  unduly against third parties and frustrate the attainment of multilateral objectives built on non-discrimination.  No government has challenged the view that the multilateral trading system must retain its primary unifying  role at the core of trade relations among nations. Given this unity of purpose, governments need to do more  to ensure the coherence and compatibility of regional trading arrangements with the multilateral trading  system. This implies a strong commitment to advancing the multilateral agenda as well as ensuring that  regional agreements are designed to support and not to compete with the WTO system.

text: Second, as governments formulate their positions in respect of the many issues on the Doha Agenda requiring  decision, an important point to keep in mind is that the effective pursuit of national interests requires joint  action around shared objectives. That means joint responsibility for an effective process of give and take.  Countries hardly ever obtain everything they want in negotiations, but it is deeply fallacious to see an outcome  yielding no result as a better option than one that might require hard work and patience, but offers something  to all parties.

text: Following a report on trends in world trade over the previous year and some observations about prospects  for the current year, WTR 2003 takes up three issues of topical interest in international trade. These are  developments in South-South trade, trends in non-oil commodity markets, and the growth of regional  trade agreements. In each case the Report analyses developments over the last few years, highlights their  implications, and draws a number of conclusions about the options facing governments.

triple: <Reliance>	<Economies reliant on basic commodities, suffering from price declines and volatility in non-oil commodity markets.>	<on>	<Developing countries depend on basic commodities due to economic reliance, leading to vulnerability from price fluctuations.>	<basic commodities>	<Commodities that developing countries are economically reliant on, contributing to their economic instability due to price declines and volatility.>
text: The Report’s analysis of trends in non-oil commodity markets highlights the well-known fact that developing  countries economically reliant on basic commodities have suffered in recent years from price declines and  continuing volatility. A range of solutions are on offer to address this problem, but some of them have proven  less than effective in the past. Fresh thinking is needed, both on the question of what can be done in respect  of the commodity markets themselves, and how developing countries might diversify their economies away  from excessive reliance on a narrow production base. Trade liberalization has a role to play, particularly in the  areas of agriculture and tariff escalation.

text: The Report’s analysis of trends in non-oil commodity markets highlights the well-known fact that developing  countries economically reliant on basic commodities have suffered in recent years from price declines and  continuing volatility. A range of solutions are on offer to address this problem, but some of them have proven  less than effective in the past. Fresh thinking is needed, both on the question of what can be done in respect  of the commodity markets themselves, and how developing countries might diversify their economies away  from excessive reliance on a narrow production base. Trade liberalization has a role to play, particularly in the  areas of agriculture and tariff escalation.

text: Focusing particularly on this last point, the Report examines how the Doha negotiations and work programme  can contribute to more effective and intensified engagement by developing countries in the WTO, building  on new opportunities generated by policy change in both developed and developing countries. The Report  divides its analysis into segments dealing with market access questions, policies aimed at facilitating openness  for development, policies for managing openness within the WTO rules, and issues relating to the possible  expansion of the WTO’s negotiating agenda. In each instance, the Report identifies basic issues and assesses  options in terms of their implications for development.

text: Second, as governments formulate their positions in respect of the many issues on the Doha Agenda requiring  decision, an important point to keep in mind is that the effective pursuit of national interests requires joint  action around shared objectives. triple: <Regional>	<Agreements that can foster regional cooperation and create trading opportunities but may also discriminate against third parties.>	<coherence and compatibility with>	<Ensures regional agreements align with the WTO system to avoid conflicting with multilateral trade objectives.>	<WTO system>	<The multilateral trading system that must retain its primary role in international trade relations.>
text: Regional trade agreements have burgeoned in the last decade or so. This can be good news and bad news.  Such agreements are good news when they bring regions closer together, create new profitable trading  opportunities and set the scene for more inclusive market-opening. They are bad news when they discriminate  unduly against third parties and frustrate the attainment of multilateral objectives built on non-discrimination.  No government has challenged the view that the multilateral trading system must retain its primary unifying  role at the core of trade relations among nations. Given this unity of purpose, governments need to do more  to ensure the coherence and compatibility of regional trading arrangements with the multilateral trading  system. This implies a strong commitment to advancing the multilateral agenda as well as ensuring that  regional agreements are designed to support and not to compete with the WTO system.

text: In the case of South-South trade, we see a marked expansionary trend, but one that is rather narrowly based  in regional terms. South-South trade clearly holds dynamic potential that could be realized more effectively  through further trade liberalization. This conclusion should in no way dilute focus on the need for continuing  liberalization efforts in respect of North-South trade, nor should it understate the need to develop the  necessary infrastructure and policy climate to facilitate South-South trade.

text: The second section of the WTR addresses a broad range of issues that are of immediate and vital interest to  the membership of the WTO. This year’s theme is trade and development. Starting from a broad although  brief discussion of development and the relationship between trade and development, the Report goes on  to analyse how the Doha Development Agenda can contribute to growth and development in developing  countries.

triple: <Regional>	<Governments are responsible for ensuring coherence and compatibility of regional trade agreements with the multilateral trading system.>	<ensure>	<Governments must ensure coherence to align regional agreements with the multilateral trading system, as per the text's emphasis on maintaining the WTO's core role.>	<coherence>	<Coherence refers to the alignment and compatibility of regional trading arrangements with the multilateral trading system.>
text: Regional trade agreements have burgeoned in the last decade or so. This can be good news and bad news.  Such agreements are good news when they bring regions closer together, create new profitable trading  opportunities and set the scene for more inclusive market-opening. They are bad news when they discriminate  unduly against third parties and frustrate the attainment of multilateral objectives built on non-discrimination.  No government has challenged the view that the multilateral trading system must retain its primary unifying  role at the core of trade relations among nations. Given this unity of purpose, governments need to do more  to ensure the coherence and compatibility of regional trading arrangements with the multilateral trading  system. This implies a strong commitment to advancing the multilateral agenda as well as ensuring that  regional agreements are designed to support and not to compete with the WTO system.

text: Written contributions were also made by Zdenek Drabek of the Economic Research and Statistics Division,  Rohini Acharya, Jacques Degbelo, Masahiro Hayafuji, Arne Klau and Angelo Silvy of the Trade Policies Review  Division and Annet Blank and Dickson Yeboah of the Institute for Training and Technical Cooperation.  Aishah  Colautti of the Economic Research and Statistics Division prepared the graphical input, Michael Engman  provided research assistance.

triple: <Range>	<A variety of solutions proposed to address the problem of price declines and volatility in non-oil commodity markets affecting developing countries.>	<of solutions>	<Indicates the set of possible solutions that are available to tackle the issue of economic challenges faced by developing countries reliant on basic commodities.>	<address problem>	<The purpose of the solutions is to resolve the issue of economic difficulties caused by price declines and volatility in non-oil commodity markets.>
text: The Report’s analysis of trends in non-oil commodity markets highlights the well-known fact that developing  countries economically reliant on basic commodities have suffered in recent years from price declines and  continuing volatility. A range of solutions are on offer to address this problem, but some of them have proven  less than effective in the past. Fresh thinking is needed, both on the question of what can be done in respect  of the commodity markets themselves, and how developing countries might diversify their economies away  from excessive reliance on a narrow production base. Trade liberalization has a role to play, particularly in the  areas of agriculture and tariff escalation.

triple: <Report>	<A report discussing trends in world trade and three topical issues in international trade.>	<in>	<The report is focused on the topic of international trade as it analyzes developments within this area.>	<international trade>	<The field of trade between countries, covering various aspects like trade agreements and commodity markets.>
text: Following a report on trends in world trade over the previous year and some observations about prospects  for the current year, WTR 2003 takes up three issues of topical interest in international trade. These are  developments in South-South trade, trends in non-oil commodity markets, and the growth of regional  trade agreements. In each case the Report analyses developments over the last few years, highlights their  implications, and draws a number of conclusions about the options facing governments.

text: Second, as governments formulate their positions in respect of the many issues on the Doha Agenda requiring  decision, an important point to keep in mind is that the effective pursuit of national interests requires joint  action around shared objectives. That means joint responsibility for an effective process of give and take.  Countries hardly ever obtain everything they want in negotiations, but it is deeply fallacious to see an outcome  yielding no result as a better option than one that might require hard work and patience, but offers something  to all parties.

text: Following a report on trends in world trade over the previous year and some observations about prospects  for the current year, WTR 2003 takes up three issues of topical interest in international trade. These are  developments in South-South trade, trends in non-oil commodity markets, and the growth of regional  trade agreements. In each case the Report analyses developments over the last few years, highlights their  implications, and draws a number of conclusions about the options facing governments.

text: Second, as governments formulate their positions in respect of the many issues on the Doha Agenda requiring  decision, an important point to keep in mind is that the effective pursuit of national interests requires joint  action around shared objectives. That means joint responsibility for an effective process of give and take.  Countries hardly ever obtain everything they want in negotiations, but it is deeply fallacious to see an outcome  yielding no result as a better option than one that might require hard work and patience, but offers something  to all parties.

triple: <policy>	<Policy measures are crucial for enhancing South-South trade by creating a supportive environment and infrastructure.>	<needed for>	<Policies are required to facilitate South-South trade due to the need for infrastructure and a favorable trade environment.>	<South-South trade>	<Trade among developing countries showing growth potential but requiring more liberalization and infrastructure development.>
text: In the case of South-South trade, we see a marked expansionary trend, but one that is rather narrowly based  in regional terms. South-South trade clearly holds dynamic potential that could be realized more effectively  through further trade liberalization. This conclusion should in no way dilute focus on the need for continuing  liberalization efforts in respect of North-South trade, nor should it understate the need to develop the  necessary infrastructure and policy climate to facilitate South-South trade.

text: Following a report on trends in world trade over the previous year and some observations about prospects  for the current year, WTR 2003 takes up three issues of topical interest in international trade. These are  developments in South-South trade, trends in non-oil commodity markets, and the growth of regional  trade agreements. In each case the Report analyses developments over the last few years, highlights their  implications, and draws a number of conclusions about the options facing governments.

text: Focusing particularly on this last point, the Report examines how the Doha negotiations and work programme  can contribute to more effective and intensified engagement by developing countries in the WTO, building  on new opportunities generated by policy change in both developed and developing countries. The Report  divides its analysis into segments dealing with market access questions, policies aimed at facilitating openness  for development, policies for managing openness within the WTO rules, and issues relating to the possible  expansion of the WTO’s negotiating agenda. In each instance, the Report identifies basic issues and assesses  options in terms of their implications for development.

triple: <third parties>	<Entities outside regional trade agreements affected by discriminatory practices.>	<discriminate against>	<Regional agreements may unfairly disadvantage third parties through preferential treatment of members.>	<regional agreements>	<Trade pacts between regions that can both promote cooperation and create discrimination issues.>
text: Regional trade agreements have burgeoned in the last decade or so. This can be good news and bad news.  Such agreements are good news when they bring regions closer together, create new profitable trading  opportunities and set the scene for more inclusive market-opening. They are bad news when they discriminate  unduly against third parties and frustrate the attainment of multilateral objectives built on non-discrimination.  No government has challenged the view that the multilateral trading system must retain its primary unifying  role at the core of trade relations among nations. Given this unity of purpose, governments need to do more  to ensure the coherence and compatibility of regional trading arrangements with the multilateral trading  system. This implies a strong commitment to advancing the multilateral agenda as well as ensuring that  regional agreements are designed to support and not to compete with the WTO system.

text: Regional trade agreements have burgeoned in the last decade or so. This can be good news and bad news.  Such agreements are good news when they bring regions closer together, create new profitable trading  opportunities and set the scene for more inclusive market-opening. They are bad news when they discriminate  unduly against third parties and frustrate the attainment of multilateral objectives built on non-discrimination.  No government has challenged the view that the multilateral trading system must retain its primary unifying  role at the core of trade relations among nations. Given this unity of purpose, governments need to do more  to ensure the coherence and compatibility of regional trading arrangements with the multilateral trading  system. This implies a strong commitment to advancing the multilateral agenda as well as ensuring that  regional agreements are designed to support and not to compete with the WTO system.

triple: <The World Trade Report>	<>	<is produced by>	<>	<WTO Secretariat>	<>
text: The World Trade Report is a new annual publication produced by the WTO Secretariat. Each year, the WTR  will explore trends in world trade and highlight important issues in the world trading system. In addition  to monitoring and interpreting trade developments, the Report seeks to deepen public understanding  of pressing policy issues. The WTR does not pretend to provide comprehensive answers to complex and  many-sided questions subject to continuing debate among governments and their constituencies. Rather, by  explaining the origin of issues and offering an analytical framework within which to address them, the WTR  aims to contribute to more informed discussion and a better appreciation of the options available to address  policy challenges.

text: The Director-General of the WTO would never declare any year unimportant or unchallenging for the  trading system. But some years are undoubtedly more momentous than others, and this is one of them.  The Fifth Ministerial Conference in Cancún in September is not the end of the Doha negotiations, but a very  important landmark on the road to completion. At Cancún, Ministers will have to take stock of progress in the  negotiations, provide political guidance and take certain decisions. This is not simply about meeting targets  and completing an agenda – it is about creating conditions for advancement in all countries, and in particular  about expanding opportunities for developing countries through their more effective inclusion in the trading  system.

text: Following a report on trends in world trade over the previous year and some observations about prospects  for the current year, WTR 2003 takes up three issues of topical interest in international trade. These are  developments in South-South trade, trends in non-oil commodity markets, and the growth of regional  trade agreements. In each case the Report analyses developments over the last few years, highlights their  implications, and draws a number of conclusions about the options facing governments.

triple: <WTO system>	<The multilateral trading system that must retain its primary unifying role in international trade relations.>	<not to compete with>	<Regional agreements should support rather than conflict with the WTO system to maintain coherence and compatibility.>	<regional agreements>	<Trading arrangements that may create profitable opportunities but risk discriminating against third parties and multilateral objectives.>
text: Regional trade agreements have burgeoned in the last decade or so. This can be good news and bad news.  Such agreements are good news when they bring regions closer together, create new profitable trading  opportunities and set the scene for more inclusive market-opening. They are bad news when they discriminate  unduly against third parties and frustrate the attainment of multilateral objectives built on non-discrimination.  No government has challenged the view that the multilateral trading system must retain its primary unifying  role at the core of trade relations among nations. Given this unity of purpose, governments need to do more  to ensure the coherence and compatibility of regional trading arrangements with the multilateral trading  system. This implies a strong commitment to advancing the multilateral agenda as well as ensuring that  regional agreements are designed to support and not to compete with the WTO system.

text: The Report’s analysis of trends in non-oil commodity markets highlights the well-known fact that developing  countries economically reliant on basic commodities have suffered in recent years from price declines and  continuing volatility. A range of solutions are on offer to address this problem, but some of them have proven  less than effective in the past. Fresh thinking is needed, both on the question of what can be done in respect  of the commodity markets themselves, and how developing countries might diversify their economies away  from excessive reliance on a narrow production base. Trade liberalization has a role to play, particularly in the  areas of agriculture and tariff escalation.

text: Following a report on trends in world trade over the previous year and some observations about prospects  for the current year, WTR 2003 takes up three issues of topical interest in international trade. These are  developments in South-South trade, trends in non-oil commodity markets, and the growth of regional  trade agreements. In each case the Report analyses developments over the last few years, highlights their  implications, and draws a number of conclusions about the options facing governments.

text: The Report’s analysis of trends in non-oil commodity markets highlights the well-known fact that developing  countries economically reliant on basic commodities have suffered in recent years from price declines and  continuing volatility. A range of solutions are on offer to address this problem, but some of them have proven  less than effective in the past. Fresh thinking is needed, both on the question of what can be done in respect  of the commodity markets themselves, and how developing countries might diversify their economies away  from excessive reliance on a narrow production base. Trade liberalization has a role to play, particularly in the  areas of agriculture and tariff escalation.

text: Focusing particularly on this last point, the Report examines how the Doha negotiations and work programme  can contribute to more effective and intensified engagement by developing countries in the WTO, building  on new opportunities generated by policy change in both developed and developing countries. The Report  divides its analysis into segments dealing with market access questions, policies aimed at facilitating openness  for development, policies for managing openness within the WTO rules, and issues relating to the possible  expansion of the WTO’s negotiating agenda. In each instance, the Report identifies basic issues and assesses  options in terms of their implications for development.

text: The World Trade Report is a new annual publication produced by the WTO Secretariat. Each year, the WTR  will explore trends in world trade and highlight important issues in the world trading system. In addition  to monitoring and interpreting trade developments, the Report seeks to deepen public understanding  of pressing policy issues. The WTR does not pretend to provide comprehensive answers to complex and  many-sided questions subject to continuing debate among governments and their constituencies. Rather, by  explaining the origin of issues and offering an analytical framework within which to address them, the WTR  aims to contribute to more informed discussion and a better appreciation of the options available to address  policy challenges.

Failure to advance will deny us all these things and dent credibility.

triple: <opportunities>	<Opportunities are to be expanded for developing countries through their more effective inclusion in the trading system.>	<are expanded for>	<The connection exists because the text emphasizes creating conditions for advancement, particularly by expanding opportunities for developing countries.>	<developing countries>	<Developing countries are to benefit from expanded opportunities through more effective inclusion in the trading system.>
text: The Director-General of the WTO would never declare any year unimportant or unchallenging for the  trading system. But some years are undoubtedly more momentous than others, and this is one of them.  The Fifth Ministerial Conference in Cancún in September is not the end of the Doha negotiations, but a very  important landmark on the road to completion. At Cancún, Ministers will have to take stock of progress in the  negotiations, provide political guidance and take certain decisions. This is not simply about meeting targets  and completing an agenda – it is about creating conditions for advancement in all countries, and in particular  about expanding opportunities for developing countries through their more effective inclusion in the trading  system.

triple: <non-oil commodity markets>	<Markets for goods other than oil, where developing countries reliant on basic commodities face challenges due to price declines and volatility.>	<analysis of trends in>	<The report examines how non-oil commodity markets have impacted developing countries through price fluctuations and volatility, highlighting economic challenges.>	<report>	<A document analyzing trends in non-oil commodity markets and their effects on developing countries' economies.>
text: The Report’s analysis of trends in non-oil commodity markets highlights the well-known fact that developing  countries economically reliant on basic commodities have suffered in recent years from price declines and  continuing volatility. A range of solutions are on offer to address this problem, but some of them have proven  less than effective in the past. Fresh thinking is needed, both on the question of what can be done in respect  of the commodity markets themselves, and how developing countries might diversify their economies away  from excessive reliance on a narrow production base. Trade liberalization has a role to play, particularly in the  areas of agriculture and tariff escalation.
